summary: When retiring police Detective William Somerset (Morgan Freeman) tackles a final case with the aid of newly transferred David Mills (Brad Pitt), they discover a number of elaborate and grisly murders. They soon realize they are dealing with a serial killer (Kevin Spacey) who is targeting people he thinks represent one of the seven deadly sins. Somerset also befriends Mills' wife, Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow), who is pregnant and afraid to raise her child in the crime-riddled city.

It's a very well made movie, beautiful to look at, and the actors are putting everything they have into it, but there's no substance. Story wise, there's nothing here. The film's thesis pretends to be that we should fight for our world, but the problem is it never commits to that thesis. John Doe, a pathetic, broken loser, wins at pretty much every step, right up until Freeman's wild tone shift with his hopeful speech that he gives despite not earning. Doe is never analyzed critically beyond what he says he is—the thing that serial killers want people to do with them—so the movie never grapples with the fact that his plot is laughable. The Seven Deadly sins thing is so surface level and lazy that it's clear Doe is just hiding behind a layer of sophistication, and his actual motivations, like most killers, are because he hates women, himself, and his society. But the movie pretends like he's much smarter than that as he executes a plan built on an elementary school understanding of Biblical thought. Any attempt to analyze it is undone by the fact that he keeps winning despite his nonsense plans. The writing consistently fails this movie, and it's obvious to me that it held together by Fincher's direction and some stellar performances.

"Se7en" is a dark and intense crime thriller that will leave a lasting impression on its viewers. Directed by David Fincher and featuring an all-star cast of Brad Pitt, Morgan Freeman, and Gwyneth Paltrow, the film takes you on a grim journey through the eyes of two detectives as they try to catch a serial killer who is using the seven deadly sins as a motif for his crimes.

The film's writing is masterful, with each twist and turn of the plot keeping the audience on the edge of their seat. The film's themes of justice, morality, and religion are explored in depth, making for a thought-provoking and haunting viewing experience.

The acting is top-notch, with Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman delivering powerful and nuanced performances as detectives David Mills and William Somerset, respectively. Meanwhile, Gwyneth Paltrow shines as Tracy, Mills' wife, adding emotional depth to the film's already heavy subject matter.

David Fincher's direction is nothing short of brilliant, with his signature visual style adding to the film's intense atmosphere. The film's score by Howard Shore adds to the film's tension and unease, while the cinematography and production design create a dark and brooding world that perfectly captures the film's themes.

In terms of editing, the film's pace is perfectly balanced, with each scene adding to the overall tension and building towards the film's unforgettable climax. The film's dialog is sharp, witty, and adds to the film's character development.

Overall, "Se7en" is a triumph of filmmaking, with its brilliant writing, powerful acting, and masterful direction making it a must-see for fans of the crime thriller genre. This film has left a lasting impact on me, and its themes and tone will stick with me for a long time to come.

Se7en is driven by Andrew Kevin Walker, the author, who raised the bar in the thriller genre. By removing the 'Judas' from the script, he placed his killer (Kevin Spacey) in the role of his own arresting officer, his own judge, and executioner of his 'judgments.'

Walker's killer gives himself up, teasing Mills (Brad Pitt) and Somerset (Morgan Freeman) to tears. Mills agonizes over the box that contains the severed head of his wife, Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow), while Somerset shouts himself hoarse, asking him not to look inside. 

Walker pens his killer in complete control right up to the finale, in which he murders Tracy, whose life he envies, and goads Mills, her wrath-ridden husband, to shoot him in the head. The terrible twins of Envy and Wrath are dispensed with in one fell swoop – brilliant authorship! 

Walker weaves the Seven Deadly Sins (Pride, Greed, Lust, Envy, Gluttony, Wrath, and Sloth) into his killer's diabolical plan while drawing inspiration from Dante, Milton, and Chaucer. He gives Somerset a break in the investigation in that the book-reading killer may have a library card with his address on it. 

In essence, Walker pens an emotional breakdown in Se7en and invites the audience down into the centrifuge to experience it. 

His other writing credits include 8mm, Sleepy Hollow, and Wolfman.

Peace!

"Se7en" is a mercilessly grisly number that is not for the squeamish, yet it would be a complete misstatement to describe the film as a challenge to be endured. In truth, we are captivated by the film's seamy and intense aesthetic from the very first frames, and those who are drawn to the crime thriller genre will surely prove unable to look away from the screen. For all of "Se7en's" heaviness, the subtly comic antagonism between the Pitt and Freeman characters provides a sly and riveting counterpoint against the dreary and perpetually rainy backdrop of the dirty city. In deliberate fashion, the film progresses along a brutal trajectory that culminates in exactly the kind of shocking climax that such a film requires to maintain thematic consistency. The overall picture that the film paints is uncompromising; devastating even, yet its artfulness is ever apparent as the film lures us in with its cruel and yet bleakly elegant symphony of events. "Se7en" is one of those rare films which I wish that I could see all over again for the first time in order to experience its shocks anew, yet on a certain level, one almost requires the security inherent in knowing what's to come.

Directed by David Fincher and starring Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman, Seven takes us down the destructive path of a biblical and sadistic serial killer out to send a message. To start of, this movie is clearly made by David Fincher and that is to be felt in every detail. There's a lot of attention given to the technical part of a police investigation, as well as the gruesome details that come with working a crime scene. The thing that stands out about this movie is the constant presence of this serial killer that is clearly steps ahead, and the pressure from working on a case where the only possibility seems waiting for the next victim to turn up. You feel the same frustration as the detectives are capable at their jobs but simply can't do much against a person that seemingly doesn't make mistakes.

That brings us to a negative as well, as toward the latter third of the movie some things seem to progress a little too easy. A few coincidences play in the main character's favours, which doesn't seem to match everything the movie was doing in the first two acts. Luckily the ending picks up and Seven tops it off with a visceral gutpunch along with great performances by everyone involved.

Very little of the murders are shown but we are appalled and shocked by what we hear of them, the action is tense and the climax is shattering. The acting is also superb, Morgan Freeman gives another brilliant performance as the disillusioned detective and Brad Pitt is great as Mills in a more meatier role than he has ever done. Gwyneth Paltrow makes a small yet significant appearance as Mill's uneasy wife, while Kevin Spacey superbly delivers equally superb dialogue as John Doe despite the fact he isn't in the film much. Overall, a brilliant film, with adept performances, direction, style and ambition. 10/10 Bethany Cox

One of the most interesting aspects with watching films from early or mid 1990's is to realize the digital development since. Back then everyone didn't have a mobile phone, not even NYPD detectives, and computers were something they used for fingerprint files. However, few films from that age, if any, still feel so modern as Se7en. Seeing Morgan Freeman, Brad Pitt and Kevin Spacey when they weren't overused but relatively fresh faces might be a factor that evokes this, but there's just something about the cinematographic style in this film that seems to have paved way for how just about every film in and around the same genre has looked stylistically ever since. The way Se7en is filmed, edited and colorized is so main school that it looks fresh even in 2022, despite the lack digital gadgets. Though it's not a copy of Silence of the Lambs, the trendsetter from four years earlier, they have many more characteristics in common than a solid serial killer plot and displaying profound psychologial features. Se7en also has several direct hints and tiny kicks to its paragon, but it obviously is and directly tries to be darker and more repulsive, quite successfully so. Regardless, despite their similarities they are both unique in their own way, and though Se7en is much more of a milestone in cinematic style innovation, Silence of the Lambs will always be the super classic, with Se7en as a very good second best.

Se7en: A Retrospective Analysis (SPOILERS)

When I first came across Se7en, it was a sad and forgetful experience. However, upon watching it again as an adult, I now realize how much I had missed, as well as how it could be a masterpiece, depending on how one interprets the final few scenes.

My scrutiny begins and ends with the astounding utilization of the last two of the seven deadly sins: envy and wrath. Before John Doe (Kevin Spacey) turns himself in, Mills (Brad Pitt) receives a note from his wife, which he never gets a chance to read. Whilst the three men, Somerset (Morgan Freeman), Mills and John Doe drive to the location with the "last two bodies", John Doe clearly and passionately states that he only kills those who are not innocent. This is especially important, as Mills' wife, from everything we know as the audience, which, in turn, is everything John Doe could possibly know about her, is an innocent person. When they arrive, they find a corpse of a wild dog, to which John Doe declares, "I didn't do THAT", emphasizing the "THAT", which helps answer Mills' question, "What's in the box?"
Not a part of Mills' wife, but rather, his dog.
Wrath can only be exercised if there is no "revenge" involved, as that would be ‘lex talionis' or ‘an eye for an eye', not blind rage. Knowing that John Doe is not an idiot who would suddenly go against his own rules, especially for the grand finale, he could effortlessly shape the situation to bring out the wrath from Mills through this final "test" without having to harm innocent civilians. Somerset, having seen what is in the box prior to Mills, realizes the dire situation he had put Mills in by leaving him alone with John Doe, who is able to easily manipulate and agitate Mills. However, Somerset is unable to tell Mills what is in the box, as that would ultimately allow John Doe to win the "game", simultaneously disallowing Somerset to determine whether or not Mills is ready to fill in his shoes once he retires from the police department. Ultimately, Mills kills John Doe without knowing what is box, exercising wrath and losing the "game". In the final scene, we see that Mills is dispirited, perhaps from finally reading the note his wife left him, only to realize that she is well, and that he had just become a sinner. Somerset decides to stay "around", as he has failed to find a worthy successor, who he believed could be Mills, had he passed John Doe's test.

This rather far-fetched take on the ending is not only plausible, but for the sake of Se7en's character continuity, also logical. Even the Se7en Wiki suggests that Mills' wife is dead, which is frivolous and perfunctory, especially given that the director clearly left the final scenes to be interpreted by the audience. Much like young me, countless theatergoers were and still are unable to see the possibilities in Se7en that completely alter the ending.

The true sin in this film was apathy and inattention; the sinners being Somerset and other citizens of Bardach County. Ironically, most of us take significant scenes at face value, unable to care or think twice about our ugly world, committing the same sins as those in Se7en.

Seven is a twisted, uncompromising vision with a level of darkness I usually only see in foreign and indie films. While it takes the premise of the typical buddy cop movie - a pair of police officers, one experienced and one green, hunting a bad guy - it is far more Insomnia or The Silence of the Lambs than Lethal Weapon. The environments are too decayed, the murders too grisly, and the setting too cynical to fit neatly into the genre. Yet, it is not exactly a serial killer film either - there is a greater emphasis on the interactions between the two partnered detectives than between the detectives and the killer. The result is a film that is sometimes difficult to watch but is also unique and innovative. On top of the quotable dialogue and dark imagery which give the film its distinctive tone, the film also features a tour de force performance by Morgan Freeman as the jaded Detective Somerset, and excellent chemistry between him and the other lead, Brad Pitt playing the young, rash Detective Mills.

So instead of showing the results of the crime, director David Fincher uses a somewhat Hitchcockian technique; by refraining to show the results of the horrible acts committed, and instead of revealing it through dialogue and acting, notably in the 'LUST' scene and 'SLOTH' scene, Fincher lets our brain do the heavy lifting and figure out what happened, and what it must have felt like. Fincher also goes out of his way to come up with the most disgusting ways a person can die, although some are admittedly tame. ('PRIDE' had it easy) The acting is incredible, featuring one of Morgan Freeman's best performances as an old, broken-down police detective, and Brad Pitt in one of his finest roles, and his acting skills are on display in his explosive acting during the finale. However, the best actor in this movie is the actor who plays John Doe. Observe his acting. Smug, self-satisfied, intelligent, analytical. His composure and fearlessness. The movie rests on this one actor to say every line perfectly. He does. His performance is just as affecting as Anthony Hopkin's in Silence of the Lambs. But the most impressive feat of all, David Fincher does something impossible: he makes the villain seem like a hero. It is hard to explain, but there are some villains that give us a glimpse into our deepest, subconscious desires. And that's terrifying. We all have parts of ourselves that we try to hide and pretend don't exist. These types of villains hold up a mirror and say, look. This is you. It's like watching a perverted car wreck that you can't look away from that hits you somewhere deep and hidden.

David Fincher's horrifying homicide detective procedural Se7en (1995) is a gripping thriller and disgusting display of human depravity. The murders are so explicit and grisly that Seven will make your stomach churn. The ghastly serial killings are so shocking and disturbing in nature that I have those scenes burned into my memory forever. It is like Fincher wanted the audience to experience how depressing and nihilistic detectives must feels after constantly witnessing the worst humanity has to offer.

Seven's story, written by Andrew Kevin Walker, is simple enough. A new hopeful detective works alongside his older experienced weary detective, who must learn to work together to capture a monstrous serial killer, as their ideals clash. Seven pulls this ideological conflict and philosophical debate to the backdrop of violent atrocity. 

Fincher's slow burn direction builds up suspense into rushes of adrenaline with his upsetting murder reveals, brilliant chase sequence, final twist, and distressing suffering. Se7en is Fincher's masterpiece painting attempted with a brush covered in blood. I cannot decide if Fincher just wanted to frighten every audience that watches Seven or if he wanted to depict the torturous existence of a man of the law. I think it's fair to say Se7en accomplishes both purposes.

Brad Pitt is brilliant in Se7en as Det. David Mills. His hopeful, fresh face is a nice contrast to Morgan Freeman's weathered face. They are the perfect foil for each other really. The energetic, wild, if unorthodox brash style of Pitt's detective are well met against Freeman's thoughtful, researched, measured, calm method. The investigation unfolds with each new clue as their bonds grow. Pitt is particularly likable and funny as well as compelling during the action sequences. You completely believe his character's emotional swings and tense nature. Pitt makes you want Mills to catch the killer all the more so. I do not think that Se7en would be as engaging without Brad Pitt's endearing performance.

Morgan Freeman is excellent as the experienced retiring Det. William Somerset. His tempered response to the violence and action around him is quite subtle. Freeman gives one of his career best performances in Se7en.

Speaking of career best acting, Kevin Spacey is chilling as John Doe. His cold and calm performance as a loathsome serial killer is unnerving, especially as he details his contempt for the people he murdered. His sudden indignant rage is also frightening unto itself.

On the other hand, Se7en features one of the few likable performances from actress Gwyneth Paltrow as Tracy Mills is really interesting as a supporting character and wife to Pitt's leading detective. Her plight of unhappiness in a new and dangerous environment is sympathetic, while Paltrow's reserved performance in the diner with Freeman is thoughtful. I really enjoyed Paltrow in Se7en.

Lastly, Howard Shore's score for Se7en gets as unnerving and suspenseful as the killings in the film. His blending of dark genres with a polished edge complements Fincher's immaculate eye for directing. Shore is as clever a composer as ever.

Overall, Se7en is a film that everyone should seek out. It's a great display of multiple acting performances. Seven an entertaining movie and a technically marvelous film. The gross messy rooms for the setting and the dingy clothes are just the surface of despair in Se7en.

Sin. It is everywhere, and everyone is doing it, and no one cares.

New York City is the inferno, and John Doe (Kevin Spacey) is intent on eradicating the deadly sins that plague it. Somerset (Morgan Freeman) and Mills (Brad Pitt) descend through the levels of hell, chasing their prey. The climax in the Ninth Circle of Hell - Treachery - provides a devastating twist.

Se7en is an intense, disturbing, bleak, thrilling film. It is dark, and hopeless, and unrelenting. The cinematography portrays the city as dirty and horrifying, reveling in excess and filth. Despite that, it also manages to elicit a sense of life and soul. Despite the oppressive atmosphere, there is some hope to be found.

Somerset and Mills are the perfect antithesis of each other. Where Somerset is pessimistic and defeated, Mills is hopeful and enthusiastic. Somerset sees only darkness in the world, and is incapable of believing that there is an end to it. Mills refuses to submit to the wickedness that lurks in each shadow, unwilling to allow it victory. Pitt and Freeman portray their characters well and their chemistry - rooted in their differences - is contagious.

Kevin Spacey is downright disturbing as John Doe. Though the character does not occupy much screen time, those few moments are captivating and chilling. The anonymity of the character, the fact that he could literally be anyone, is horrifying in its own right.

Se7en is a film that one could view multiple times, and come away with something different each time. The correlation to Dante's Inferno is intriguing, and it's interesting to see the deadly sins manifest in Somerset and Mills themselves.

In a literal sea of crime thrillers, Se7en's unique qualities set it far and above its peers.

Se7en is a psychological thriller starring Morgan Freeman and Brad Pitt, which places Detectives Mills (Pitt) and Somerset (Freeman) chasing after a serial killer. Somerset's upcoming retirement allows his character to arc from a disgruntled old cop who wants to finish his duties to one who is eventually truly fascinated by the serial killer's use of classic literature and elaborate illustrations of the seven deadly sins. The cinematography and lighting in the film are common threads that allude to the sad world that we live in. There is always dim lighting and constant rain and poverty are shown throughout the city. This film provides moral commentary centered around the seven deadly sins and is constant throughout. Detective Mill's wife Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow) plays what appears to be a minor role but her character development throughout the film is an interesting foreshadowing for what is an incredibly exciting ending. While the film may be a little slow at times, it certainly fits the psychological thriller genre and keeps the viewer from being prepared for obvious outcomes. The film's ending has a vague resolution, which differs from typical thrillers where the archetypical hero comes out clean in the end. Early on, it becomes obvious that there will be seven murders based on the seven deadly sins but the conflict has its fair share of twists and turns as Detectives Mills and Somerset battle against themselves and a highly educated serial killer who is meticulous beyond belief. This film gets a 3.5 / 5 rating, where the focus is on the incredible visuals and cinematography portrayed throughout.

The rain never stops, color never bears a warmth, murders seem endless, and humanity is left floating.  If "Se7en" doesn't depict a hell on Earth then I don't know what does.  Cold and dark, it is the kind of film you appreciate for its down-trodden intelligence, its elusive whodunit stylings - but you are left gazing at it from afar like an art museum piece.  To get too close might change you in ways to haunting to admit.  It is more about the horrific evils the human race is capable of than it is about its focal mystery, and such meditations keep it from doing anything other than disturbing.  The film is relentlessly gloomy.
	I think it has stuck with audiences for so long because it so emotionally sadistic.  No other mainstream thriller has ever gone as far as "Se7en" has, and I don't think another one ever will.  Before it was even made, executives wanted it to be more action-based, less grisly - the version seen on screen is a rough draft accidentally sent to the then-rising David Fincher ("The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo," "Gone Girl"), who was intrigued by what he read and fought (successfully) to get the darker version in theaters.  Unless you count "Alien 3," his first foray into cinema that he himself has admitted to disliking, "Se7en" is among the most callous debuts in film history.  It sets the tone for his remarkable career, which has, more than once, pondered how gritty realism can meet (and clash) with commercial entertainment values (though I'm sure he'll never be able to match the barbarousness of "Se7en" quite so ferociously ever again).
	Brad Pitt nor Morgan Freeman have ever been met with such dark material either.  In the film, Pitt is David Mills, an upstart, young detective who flirts with anger management and who flirts with brilliance.  Freeman is Det. William Somerset, a grizzled old pro only days away from much needed retirement.  Mills has just moved with his pretty wife, Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow), in order to bask in frequently rewarding cases located in the bad part of town the film notably takes place in.  Somerset, with his seen-it-all cynicism, wants nothing more than to get away from the bleakness that so constantly surrounds him.
	But then a case lands in their laps too horrific to ignore - a serial killer, emotionless and nefarious, is murdering innocent individuals in a way that pits their deaths against the Seven Deadly Sins.  For Gluttony, he forces an obese man to eat until his stomach bursts, for example.  Mills is excited by the case and the fame that could occur following its solving, but Somerset, wanting to leave his job on a good note, begs his superior to let someone else handle the investigation.  Neither, however, realize just how personal the case will soon become.
	"Se7en" begins as an unusually astute police procedural involving in all the right ways, from the way we become fiendishly curious as to how the killer will strike next to the emotional connection we feel for its leading characters, all flawlessly portrayed by Pitt, Freeman, and Paltrow.  But as the film snakes along do we begin to notice that, even once the case is solved, such fearful crimes will only continue in this land where the sun doesn't shine; who knows how long it will be before another obsessive murderer wreaks havoc upon the community? 
	The contrast between the characters of Mills and Somerset is dynamic.  Mills purposely got himself transferred to Somerset's district in search of more adrenaline in his work, as if to be completely unaware that more crime means more hellaciousness - even one's personal life could be changed by such tawdriness.  Somerset has experienced every case imaginable, and, despite warning Mills that taking on the investigation will not end happily, his counterpart is too dangerously compelled (as we are) to realize that getting as far as possible from the situation is the better route to take.  They don't like each other in the way friends do - we can see that Somerset views Mills as a sort of son, protective of his vocational innocence and worried about how his marriage will be affected through living in this dangerous, noiry part of the city.  
	The killer, who I will not mention the name of in order to retain the secrecy of his identity kept upon "Se7en"'s release, is portrayed with methodical cool reminiscent of Hannibal Lecter.  Though we know that they are insane, that bloodlust is not a natural human genetic, their intelligence causes us to believe that they are still somehow superior to us, somehow more perceptive of the world, even if this standpoint is, in truth, false.  He is not revealed until the very last act of the film, but his capture is a part of his plan.  Some argue that Lecter is a screen villain villainous to enough to fill the blank spaces of other serial killer films, the evilest of the evil, but "Se7en"'s madman seems to be just a little more in love with being cruel - he finds joy in the destruction of another person's life, and that makes him absolutely terrifying.  
	I will warn, though, that you will be more repulsed by "Se7en" than you will be bewitched by it like "The Silence of the Lambs." The latter does not surround graphic crime scenes with the brutal fashion like "Se7en" does, being more about the magnetism of the investigation than anything.  And it shows off a relatively happy ending, with Jodie Foster being a heroine for the ages.  But "Se7en" is blood-soaked at nearly every corner; when it isn't, it is deeply melancholy, in a way that suggests nothing will ever get better.  I could never become emotionally involved with it (aside from its characters) - it is too icy to experience on a humane level - but that doesn't stop me from praising how it doesn't conform to mainstream cinema fakery.  In a world this black, there shouldn't be a happy ending.

The dark look of the film perfectly matches the tone, the shot selection always seems to be spot-on, and he deserves all the praise in the world for fighting the studio to keep the ending as written. While I will avoid spoiling that ending on the off chance someone hasn't seen it, it is a true masterpiece that adds so much weight to the film. I was absolutely stunned the first time I watched Se7en and sat silently in my seat for more than 10 minutes after it ended in total shock. This is a film that people will still be talking about 50 years from now, and it will be spoken of as a classic of our generation. There are few movies like this that can suck me in from the first frame of the film and hold my attention completely for more than 2 hours, even though I already know what's going to happen. Brad Pitt is great as the young detective who is new to town. He has an ego which fits someone who has risen so high already at his age but he also provides most of the, admittedly rare, laughs in the film. He has a tendency to be friendly but also a bit reserved because the city has jaded him so much. Naturally, a film about a serial killer is pretty dark and intense stuff. There's a decent amount of gore and disturbing material that will not sit well with some viewers. While I don't know if it's really a criticism, there are people who will be disgusted by Se7en, so it doesn't have that kind of mass appeal that other masterpieces of cinema have. Even I can't bear to watch it all that often because it's a heavy film, not one you can just throw on and munch on popcorn. Yet I think the mastery of this film is in the restraint that Fincher shows. Many of the most gruesome and awful things in this film are only described rather than seen. However, the details are so specific that our minds fill in the blanks to the point where people who have seen the film will often swear they saw something that was never actually shown on camera. And for those moments when we do see some detail of the murders it is necessary in order to tell the tale and to help us understand the insane passion of John Doe. There are very few movies with a climax as tough to take as Se7en. It almost forces you as a viewer to go through the same thought process as the main characters and wonder what the right thing is to do at that point, and whether we WANT them to do the right thing. As you can see Se7en is a film I could spend hours praising and going into every detail about its genius. If you haven't seen it and you think you can take it, then it would be a sin if you didn't check it out sometime.

There are few films which can lay claim to scenes which shook the world, or at least the people watching. Alien had the Chestburster, Silence of the Lambs had that first meeting with Hannibal Lecter, Se7en has the box. A simple cardboard box that gives way to an ending which literally rivals the best cinema has to offer. 

But I'm getting ahead of myself. Se7en follows detectives Mills and Somerset as they try to track down a serial killer whose pattern is that of the seven deadly sins. 

David Fincher has been lauded as some sort of a technical genius recently, especially with his incredible work in the Social Network, but at the time of making Se7en, his reputation was somewhat different. After a long line of music videos, Fincher finally made the move in the movie world with the disappointing Alien 3. Basically, it was time to prove himself. All it takes is the opening credits sequence to do so. Set to a Nine Inch Nails remix, the credits themselves set the mood and tone for the rest of the film brilliantly. From then on, Fincher creates a Blade Runner-esque noir feel to a crumbling city which, lacking a physical evildoer, becomes the villain against Mills and Somerset's dual protagonists. Fincher, whilst living in his previous movies' shadow, isn't afraid to make some bold choices in terms of shooting, working with some disorientating handheld shots to great effect and beautifully obscuring his villain until the reveal. He may not have been the virtuoso that he is now but it's an incredible starting point. Despite the urge to occasionally close-in on a gory set-piece, Fincher restrains from gratuity in many cases, preferring to let our minds do the work that the production team doesn't. The fact that we don't actually see any of the killings is tribute to this fact, but what Fincher shows us in the aftermath is more shocking than any amount of violence alone could do. Fincher also makes sure to focus on the relationships of the piece. The ending being the way it is, it wouldn't work if the emotional connection to the viewer hadn't been set up in the first place. Fincher does this with incredible precision without sacrificing his films grimy tone. It truly is a masterful piece of directing which only began to show his potential for films to come. 

Andrew Kevin Walker's script is at once sympathetic and diabolical, especially in the way that it knowingly sets the viewer up to be crushed towards the end. The book which the film is based on may be the starting point for this, but Walker's incredible depth of emotion and knack for realistic dialogue means that this is achieved with that much more impact. The dialogue between Mills and Somerset is beautifully written, achieving a realistic relationship between the two without rushing it along. The natural evolution of a working relationship to start with, then to a true friendship is a brilliant achievement by Walker. It would be easy to shoehorn these two characters into something easily recognisable and clichéd for the sake of time, but it's much more rewarding to see it play out the way it does. The two character Walker brings to life are intricately layered and filled with nuance, even while still on the page. 

But the two characters would stay there if it wasn't for Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman's incredible portrayal of the two. Pitt plays Mills, the new guy in town, who is enthusiastic to the point of impatience and who doesn't quite know how to act around people. Despite his initial abrasiveness, Pitt imbues him with such a goofy charm that, even when he's busy tripping over his tongue, he is incredibly likeable. The stark contrast between his demeanour at the office and his attitude at home is played with clever subtlety by Pitt creating a more rounded character than that of your typical buddy-cop movie. His interaction with Gwyneth Paltrow is fantastic as well, being careful to play down the obvious love that he holds for her which makes their relationship seem all the more real. Paltrow's performance here is similarly fantastic, a symbol of hope for most of the characters in the film. Her conversation with Somerset is as emotional as it should be without being a drama and her connection with Mills is that of a young, but clearly in love, couple. Morgan Freeman's performance is amazing as always, but here his godlike unshakable attitude pays off better than other times. His subtle shift towards uncertainty and finally terror is an incredible thing to watch as we see his vainly trying to grasp at the last vestiges of control that he has over his circumstances. It's truly an amazing performance but, then again, it's Morgan Freeman. It's difficult to imagine him turning in anything else. Kevin Spacey, though he's only in the film for a short amount of time, makes an indelible impression on the film. His ranting, just short of manic, performance shows off exactly what Spacey has become famous for; his chameleon-like ability to become any role. Though my favourite performance of his has to be Lester Burnham, this would definitely be a close second next to Verbal Kint. His cold, detached stare which occasionally gives way to furious, operatic speeches is an amazing thing to watch. Richard Schiff, a vastly underrated performer, snatches a few minutes of screen time and turns in a brilliantly murky performance. His smug attitude and impenetrable demeanour make him hypnotic to watch. It's sad he doesn't get to be onscreen for longer. John C. Reilly also makes an appearance in the film, miles away from his jovial Dr. Cox and more towards his character in Platoon without all the cowardice. Bit-parts such as the surviving victim of lust also make for incredible performances but it's these central ones which stick in the mind the longest. 

Se7en is a testament and origin point for David Fincher's prowess as a filmmaker, a film noir worthy to be mentioned with the likes of Blade Runner and a horror to stand the test of time. Not for the faint hearted.

Seven is a dark film. Composed with admirable technique on a technical front, and utterly shocking and brutal on a storytelling basis. Director David Fincher's second major feature film is considered his most grim, gruesome and demented, and after viewing it for the first time, I can do little but nod my head in agreement. Centring around a pair of detectives, one of them a loud, naive and boisterous individual who also happens to be relatively trigger happy and buys into the conventional hero type, and his partner being a secluded, hidden and emotionally cloaked man who understands the true pain and frustration associated with his undesirable occupation. The film follows them as they try to track down a killer who utilizes the seven deadly sins to execute innocent victims; he is a man who lacks visual empathy or sympathy, and respects those who track him correctly. We watch as the two detectives pull themselves apart emotionally, looking for the man who tests the boundaries of moral and societal acceptance and ambiguity, and threatens their own very sanity. Seven is a sick, twisted horrifying picture, that whilst not always compelling, demands utter attention.

We start with a grizzly death. A fat man, head laying within a dish of pasta. It's raining outside. Obviously, we aren't there, but we feel the cold seeping through into the dark room that we're confronted with. Fincher's cinematographer and gaffer, Darius Khondji and Chris Strong respectively, immediately set the tone of the film; the negatives are cold and edgy, and the lights that shine through holes and windows are slight, providing atmosphere instead of any relief. It's raining outside, which happens to be perhaps one of my favourite things about the opening scenes in this film. Seven starts slowly, and this is undeniably the least applaudable section of the running time. The characters are initially not as compelling as one would desire, and whilst the camera work captures the dark and twisted feeling of the rest of the movie, we aren't yet caught up in Fincher's story. As Brad Pitt's character, the younger detective named Mills, is introduced, I was not initially impressed with the actors performance. It was crude and reflective of the time period and the characters personality, but the delivery felt weak, not fully invested. Perhaps this was the intention of Pitt or Fincher? Nevertheless, it isn't worthy of commendation from my point of view.

We're introduced to the case and the characters and all those involved, but we don't really care. Neither Mills nor Freeman's character, Somerset, are particularly interesting. Do not fear; this will change down to the track. For the time being though, we aren't fully invested in what's going on. Fincher is introducing us to the look of the picture, and he, along with screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker seem to forget to provide us with enthralling material. This is the first fifteen minutes. We see another murder, and we're introduced to the gimmick behind the picture; the killer is utilizing the seven deadly sins. I, unlike many, do not care if a film is based around a gimmick, so long as the characters are provided with interesting back stories and meaning. At this point, I'm not invested in anyone or anything in particular, so I'm irritated with where the film is heading. And then suddenly, almost without warning, the film seems to explode with vitality, energy sprouting as the case and the performances and the writing and everything all seeming to quicken up, the story becoming instantaneously more interesting. Somerset finds a clue from the second murder scene, and suddenly we get backstory into his personality and life. We get information on Mills, his child-like ways, as well as his beautiful wife, named Tracy and played by the dreaded Gwyneth Paltrow. Suddenly, the gimmick is only part of the picture, not the entirety of it.

The characters hurdle through the plot, and we witness the tedious life of a detective, which involves writing, taking calls, thinking. But the film never feels slow or held down by this: we're provided with hunks of tension, so much that I was on the edge of my seat half the running time, even if there really wasn't anything going on. Fincher's minimalist cinematography combined with the gloomy atmosphere help to build up a sense of dread within the viewer. We understand that something just has to happen. Someone is going to die, or they're going to stumble onto something they shouldn't. Mills and Somerset rush to stop the killer, but they have to deal with their own differing opinions in regards to what being a detective means. They debate on their styles, which include Mills kicking down doors and intruding upon privately-owned space, and Somerset understanding the slow and tedious life they life in reality. The film is never bogged down by these portions; in fact, they are part of the most entertaining portions. As the film rushes to its climax, these characters become the focal point, as does the killer, and we reflect on their development and being.

And then the climax happens.

And whereas Seven was vying for an acceptable rating prior to this point, it not only exceeds my expectations, but proves to be one of the most shocking and frightening finales I've ever had the grace of viewing. The development and dialogue on the meaning of human innocence, moral impurity and misunderstanding finally give way to the shocking ending, which delivers gut punches to the viewer left, right and centre. Andrew Kevin Walker; stand up and take a bow. There are great final acts, and then there is the final act of Jaws, and then there is the final act of How To Train Your Dragon. And then there is the final act of Seven. It's unpredictable and beautifully filmed; the finale is the only portion of the picture filmed with sun and clarity. The murky and unsettling story of the rest of the film gives way to pitch-perfect comprehensibility. Both visually and in terms of storytelling, Seven finally proves why it is beloved by nearly all who view it, thanks to this conclusion which rattles the viewer to the core.

So perhaps it's not perfect. The characters aren't initially all that interesting, and the movie doesn't start shocking until at least fifteen minutes into its running time. But after that, Fincher doesn't just pick up the pace; he starts sprinting. Never is there a dull moment. The picture tricks you into thinking every minute or sequence is important, and we thank it for it. A film which can entertain without missing a beat is always appreciated, and Seven does exactly that. Pitt and Freeman, after their preliminary scenes, prove to deliver two of the performances of their careers. Fincher's glum direction and pacing leaves the viewer with little time to feel bored or lacking tension, and we soak it in and appreciate it. Cinematographer Darius Khondji's work is beautiful, cleanly cut and always precise. He provides the usual Fincher look; as if we're viewing this picture from afar, witnessing the events from the side. The lighting technicians and the aforementioned gaffer, Chris Strong, provide an atmosphere that the film often relies on, and it benefits from immensely. Even Howard Shore's score is effective, and I often criticise the atrocious musical taste that David Fincher has! Shore actual understands musical coherence, instead of the crap that Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross pump out. I've only seen 3 David Fincher films, and this one fares in the middle: The Social Network I gave an 8.8, Gone Girl I awarded 9.8, and Seven I award a 9.2. This is a competent, harrowing, somewhat uneven but undeniably powerful suspense thriller that doesn't let go until the very last second.

A gritty, wet and filthy neo-noir of the late 20th century, Se7en remains as both a quintessential crime noir tale, and one of David Fincher's defining work as a director. Se7en is ultimately as an intricately crafted film that uses the horror of humanity as a commentary into the two opposing sides of it, constantly engaged in a struggle for dominance over the other. Se7en focuses on a theme of a persisting and omnipresent evil, and it doesn't shy away from constantly reminding the audience of it through David Fincher's stellar direction, which ultimately breathed life into visualizing Andrew Walker's script.

The events in Se7en are constantly draped with a depressing, ominous feeling, and you can't help feel nothing but dread throughout the whole film. Crimes are shown in passing glimpses, under the cover of heavy downpour. Characters speak of vile acts they've seen or experienced in the city. A city which has no name or identifiable identity. One whose ambiguity could mean that it could very well be any city in America, and even extends out to any other city in the world.

Then there are the downright brutal, calculative murders that Detective Mills and Somerset are tasked with solving. Can anyone ever forget the Sloth murder? The first few murders are a play on the audience's visual senses, and then it evolves into a play on the audience's imagination. Murders aren't shown, but teased in controlled portions of the screen, through pictures of the 'tools' used and through the narration of characters, be it overtly or subtly, using the imagination of the viewer against them.

Detective William Somerset, originally written with John Hurt in mind, is played excellently by Morgan Freeman, who utilizes his iconic warm, yet authoritative voice to the best of his capabilities as the grizzled, veteran detective who has to ease his replacement, Detective David Mills, into his position. Brad Pitt himself plays Mills amazingly as a fast-talking, witty young hotshot detective, and both Freeman and Pitt have that natural chemistry, as the actors play off their actual difference in age and talent - one is a young hotshot actor, and the other is a veteran, experienced actor - to their advantage when portraying their characters.

While this isn't exactly something new, back then or even now, to have cops with different views, principles or approach to their jobs to become partners, and then have a film based around it, Se7en is the only serious film that this particular premise has truly worked in for me.The killer, a literal and figurative John Doe, is both fleshed out, and paradoxically, not fleshed out.

Towards the end, Mills and Somerset finally learn about this monstrosity that they've been chasing, and everything is presented in fractured pieces that certain parts of the audience might piece together, or might consider a disjointed mess. It is at this point, that the audience either becomes Detective Mills or Detective Somerset; one plays off the killer as a simple, downright lunatic, while the other sees the bigger picture of this particular brand of lunacy, and prods and questions it further.

Story: Director David Fincher's dark, stylish thriller ranks as one of the decade's most influential box-office successes. Set in a hellish vision of a New York-like city, where it is always raining and the air crackles with impending death, the film concerns Det. William Somerset (Morgan Freeman), a homicide specialist just one week from a well-deserved retirement. Every minute of his 32 years on the job is evident in Somerset's worn, exhausted face, and his soul aches with the pain that can only come from having seen and felt far too much. But Somerset's retirement must wait for one last case, for which he is teamed with young hotshot David Mills (Brad Pitt), the fiery detective set to replace him at the end of the week. Mills has talked his reluctant wife, Tracy (Gwyneth Paltrow), into moving to the big city so that he can tackle important cases, but his first and Somerset's last are more than either man has bargained for. A diabolical serial killer is staging grisly murders, choosing victims representing the seven deadly sins. First, an obese man is forced to eat until his stomach ruptures to represent gluttony, then a wealthy defense lawyer is made to cut off a pound of his own flesh as penance for greed. Somerset initially refuses to take the case, realizing that there will be five more murders, ghastly sermons about lust, sloth, pride, wrath, and envy presented by a madman to a sinful world. Somerset is correct, and something within him cannot let the case go, forcing the weary detective to team with Mills and see the case to its almost unspeakably horrible conclusion. The moody photography is by Darius Khondji; the nauseatingly vivid special effects are by makeup artist Rob Bottin, best known for more fantasy-oriented work in films like The Howling (1981).

David Fincher's Seven is one of the most well made and well crafted mystery films of all time. This is a fantastically well made, dark and disturbing film that I just love. This film stars Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman and both of them are fantastic. Both of the characters are cliches but the brilliant thing is both Pitt and Freeman are so good that they make you forget they are playing cliches. Brad Pitt is great and his character could've been quite annoying but he's great and Pitt gets to really prove how great he is in the ending of this film. Morgan Freeman however steals the show and this is one of his best performances. His character is again a huge cliche but he's great and gives an Oscar worthy performance. Gwyneth Paltrow gives probably her best performance I've seen. This movie is also amazingly directed by David Fincher who keeps this film nail bitingly tense throughout and gives us possibly the best movie ending ever. The writing is also fantastic as this film just never lets up and is a very disturbing film. Seven is known as one of the most disturbing films ever and yeah it is but it was a great choice from Fincher to decide to only show the aftermath of the murders because if he had showed the murders this film just would have been too much. One of the most disturbing sections here is the Lust sequence; we don't see anything in this scene only the aftermath buts it's just so disturbing due to the suggestion and implication and a fantastic performance from Leland Orser. This film is extremely tense, especially the chase scene and the ending. Speaking of which Seven has one of the best endings ever. As in mentioned it's extremely tense and disturbing but it's also very emotional. Seven is a technical masterpiece with amazing cinematography and lighting which makes the city the film is set seem almost like a character. The way the city is presented is amazing and is an extremely gritty and harsh environment. Fincher also decided to never say where the film is set which makes this film even more disturbing as you feel like the film could happen anywhere. The editing is also great and this film is never boring. I don't really have any problems here this film is just that good. Seven is masterpiece of a film and one of Fincher's best along with Fight Club. This is a fantastic film. A+
